user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemGetInfo(osal_id_t sem_id, OS_mut_sem_prop_t *mut_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(mut_prop);

    memset(mut_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_mut_sem_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_mutex_table, token);

        strncpy(mut_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(mut_prop->name) - 1);
        mut_prop->creator = record->creator;

        return_code = OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl(&token, mut_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_mutex_table
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
} OS_mut_sem_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
int32 OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_mut_sem_prop_t *mut_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No language/compiler extensions were found in the provided code fragments. Specifically:
- OS_MutSemGetInfo uses only standard C constructs: local variables, calls, standard library functions (memset, strncpy), and standard pointer usage.
- The macros shown (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) expand to ordinary C expressions and do not include compiler-specific extensions in their provided definitions.
- The extern declaration (extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_mutex_table) and typedefs are standard C.
- No occurrences of known compiler extensions are present in the provided text (no __attribute__, __asm, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }) used as an expression, nested functions, nonstandard keywords, or other vendor-specific tokens).

Caveat: Some identifiers referenced but not defined here (for example BUGCHECK, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, or other macros/implementations not shown) could themselves use compiler-specific extensions. Those definitions were not provided; if they contain compiler-specific extensions, those specific definitions should be reviewed. Based solely on the code and definitions shown, there are no fragments that require investigation for Rule 1.2.
